title: Determining "Redistributability"
content:
Good day!

I am a designer/technical writer at a software company and am having a difficult time determining whether or not we can develop a documents package that includes Myriad Pro. The end user would receive this typeface a part of our software installation process; I just can't seem to figure out how to find accurate information on this subject. Someone at typophile should be able to tell me!:

**What do I need to do to determine--WITH ABSOLUTE CONFIDENCE--the legality of distributing this font?**

Put another way: we are considering incorporating Myriad Pro into an installation that would affect 40,000 (yes, 40k) computers.

Thanks in advance for your advice!
author: phont_phace

comments.content: If reading the licence agreement isn’t enough, how about asking Adobe?

[Adobe's Font Licensing Center](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317132951/http:/www.adobe.com/products/type/font-licensing.html) should have answers to your questions. It also includes contact information so that you can email someone directly if you need a more detailed or specific answer.

Thanks to you both. I sent my inquiry to Adobe and received just the information I needed in a response from Typekit staff. This definitely put the kibosh on using Myriad Pro for our development effort, hehe (As it turns out, this would have probably gone on 50k+ systems). Here's the email, in the off chance that it may help someone else!

**"At this time, we don't offer licenses for inclusion in apps. We hope to in the future, but don't have such a program at this time. In the meantime, I recommend that you use the App+ program from FontShop. [www.fontshop.com](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317132951/http:/www.fontshop.com/ "www.fontshop.com") They won't be able to offer you Myriad, but they have a nice selection of fonts at reasonable prices."**

Cheers!
